event: The Nineteenth Amendment grants women the right to vote
National Women's Party proposes Constitutional Amendment: "Men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and in every place subject to its jurisdiction."
Radice v. New York upholds a law forbidding waitresses from working the night shift with the exception of entertainers and ladies' room attendants
Indian Citizenship Act grants Native Americans the right to vote
The National Recovery Act forbids more than one family member from holding a government job, resulting in many women losing their jobs
The National Recovery Act forbids more than one family member from holding a government job, resulting in many women losing their jobs
United States v. One Package of Japanese Pessaries gives judicial approval to the medicinal use of birth control
Supreme Court upholds Washington State's minimum wage laws for women
The Fair Labor Standards Act establishes minimum wage without regard to sex
Fay v. New York rules that women are equally qualified to men to serve on juries but are granted an exemption if the women choose
Hoyt v. Florida upholds Florida rules making it far less likely for women to be called for jury service than men because a "woman is still regarded as the center of home and family life."
Hoyt v. Florida upholds Florida rules making it far less likely for women to be called for jury service than men because a "woman is still regarded as the center of home and family life."
The Equal Pay Act promises equitable wages for the same work regardless of race, color, religion, national origin, or sex
Title VII of the Civil Rights Act prohibits employment discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, or sex
Weeks v. Southern Bell opens many previously male-only jobs to women
Executive Order 11246 prohibits sex discrimination by government contractors and requires affirmative action plans for hiring women
Bowe v. Colgate-Palmolive Company rules that women can work in traditionally men-only jobs if they meet the physical requirements
California adopts the nation's first "no fault" divorce law allowing divorce by mutual consent
Phillips v. Martin Marietta Corporation outlaws the practice of refusing to hire women who have pre-school aged children
Phillips v. Martin Marietta Corporation outlaws the practice of refusing to hire women who have pre-school aged children
Reed v. Reed declares unconstitutional an Idaho law establishing automatic preference for men as administrators of wills and declares women as "persons"
Title IX of the Education Amendments prohibits sex discimination in all education programs that receive federal support
Eisenstadt v. Baird rules that the right to privacy protects an unmarried person's right to use contraceptives
Pittsburgh Press v. Pittsburgh Commission on Human Relations bans sex-segregated "help wanted" advertising
Roe v. Wade makes abortion legal in the U.S.
Housing and credit discrimination based on sex are outlawed
Cleveland Board of Education v. La Fleur prohibits companies from forcing maternity leave
Cleveland Board of Education v. La Fleur prohibits companies from forcing maternity leave
The Women's Educational Equity Act funds the development of nonsexist teaching materials to encourage full educational opportunities for women
The Women's Educational Equity Act funds the development of nonsexist teaching materials to encourage full educational opportunities for women
The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Justice and Labor Departments, and AT&T agree to end AT&T's discriminatory practices against women and minorities
Taylor v. Louisiana denies States the right to exclude women from juries
Craig v. Boren declares unconstitutional a state law permitting 18 to 20-year-old females to drink beer, but not males
The Pregnancy Discrimination Act
The Pregnancy Discrimination Act
Excluding women from the draft ruled Constitutional
Kirchberg v. Feenstra overturns State laws giving husbands unilateral control of property
Mississippi ratifies the 19th Amendment
Hishon v. King and Spaulding rules that law firms may not discriminate by sex in hiring partnerships
Meritor Savings Vank v. Vinson holds that companies can be prosecuted for sexual harassment
Webster v. Reproductive Health Services affirms the right of States to deny public funding for abortions and to prohibit public hospitals from performing abortions
Harris v. Forklift Systems, Inc. rules that a victim need not prove physical or serious psychological industry to claim sexual harassment
Family and Medical Leave Act
Family and Medical Leave Act
Gender Equity in Education Act
Gender Equity in Education Act
Gender Equity in Education Act
Gender Equity in Education Act
College athletics programs must actively involve roughly equal numbers of men and women to qualify for federal support

Burlington Industries, Inc. v. Ellerth and Faragher v. City of Boca Raton rules that employees are liable for sexual harassment even when threats are not acted upon unless the supervisor took immediate action to correct the behavior
United States v. Morrison rules that victims of sexual violence cannot sue their attackers in federal court
Hillary Clinton becomes the first First Lady elected to public office
Condoleezza Rice becomes the first Black woman Secretary of State
Jackson v. Birmingham Board of Education rules that complaining about sex-based discrimination is not punishable
Enforcement of the Violence Against Women Act, reallocation of funds
The Supreme Court upholds ban on partial-birth abortion
Nancy Pelosi becomes the first woman Speaker of the House
Hillary Clinton becomes the first First Lady to run for President
Sonia Sotomayor becomes the first Latinx American and third woman Supreme Court Justice
Hillary Clinton becomes Secretary of State
The Affordable Health Care Act requires private health insurance companies to cover birth control
Women can have military combat positions
Captain Kristen Griest and First Lieutenant Shaye Haver are the first women soldiers to graduate from the Ranger school
U.S. Treasury announces designs for currency featuring women of history
Hillary Clinton becomes the first woman to lead the national ticket for a major political party
Hillary Clinton loses presidential election to Donald Trump
Women's March on Washington
First Latinx woman senator, Catherine Cortez Masto, takes office among a record number of congresswomen
First openly transgender state legislator, Danica Roem, takes office in Virginia.
Oregon becomes the first state to offer a "non-binary" option on its drivers licences
Alyssa Milano, following Tarana Burke, posts a tweet with the hashtag #MeToo, unleashing a global conversation about sexual harassment
Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez becomes youngest woman elected to congress, among a record-setting 116 additional women
Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib become first Muslim women elected to congress
Sharice Davids amd Deb Haaland become the first Indigenous women elected to congress
Cardi B becomes the first woman solo performer to win a Best Rap Album Grammy for "Invasion of Privacy"
The US Women's National Soccer team wins the World Cup while initiating an equal pay lawsuit
16-year-old Greta Thunberg lands in New York to appear at a climate change protest, and is named TIME's person of the year
Kamala Harris launches presidential campaign; in 2020, she will join Joe Biden's ticket to become the first woman, and first Black woman, to be elected Vice President
